thread.title: McCaskill to oppose Sessions as attorney general
thread.title_full: McCaskill to oppose Sessions as attorney general

author: Chuck Raasch St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: McCaskill to oppose Sessions as attorney general
text:
Close Andrew Harnik 
In this photo taken Jan. 10, 2017, Attorney General-designate, Sen. Jeff Sessions, R-Ala. testifies on Capitol Hill in Washington. The top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee plans to request a delay in the confirmation vote on President Donald Trump's nominee for attorney general, a move that will push the panel's vote back to Jan. 31. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik) McCaskill to oppose Sessions as attorney general ( … ) Andrew Harnik 
In this photo taken Jan. 10, 2017, Attorney General-designate, Sen. Jeff Sessions, R-Ala. testifies on Capitol Hill in Washington. The top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee plans to request a delay in the confirmation vote on President Donald Trump's nominee for attorney general, a move that will push the panel's vote back to Jan. 31. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik) 
WASHINGTON • Sen. Claire McCaskill will vote against President Donald Trump's attorney general nominee, fellow Sen. Jeff Sessions. 
McCaskill, a former county prosecutor in Kansas City, announced her decision Tuesday, citing past Session votes against reauthorization of a law aimed at putting more resources to fight, and toughening penalties for, violent crimes against women, and his support of enhanced interrogation of terror suspects. 
McCaskill, D-Mo., issued a statement: 
“As a former prosecutor, I know the power and essence of the position of Attorney General is deciding who and what to prosecute, and where to put the priorities and resources of the massive power of federal law enforcement. Sen. Sessions’ vote against the Violence Against Women Act, and his vote for torture tactics, are a window into how he would use that power. Therefore, I cannot support his confirmation.” 
Earlier Tuesday, McCaskill, along with Sens. Dick Durbin, D-Ill.; and Tammy Duckworth, D-Ill., were among the 50 senators to vote against Trump's education secretary nominee, Betsy DeVos. DeVos won confirmation when Vice President Mike Pence broke the tie. Political Fix from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch
